byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger reported from Paris and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura reported from Brussels. Milan Schreuer in Brussels and Aurelien Breeden and Elian Peltier in Paris contributed reporting.
byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

abstract: France and Belgium, stunned and rattled by Paris terror attacks, take bold steps to bolster their security forces, sparking debate over balancing counterterrorism moves with civil liberties; governments are for now clearly putting safety of citizens ahead of other concerns.
lead_paragraph: The two nations are each acting to toughen emergency powers in the wake of the Paris attacks, but some wonder if the cost to personal liberty is too great.

headline.main: As France and Belgium Strengthen Security, a Classic Debate Arises
headline.print_headline: A Rattled Europe Tilts Toward Bolder Security, Starting a Rights Debate

snippet: The two nations are each acting to toughen emergency powers in the wake of the Paris attacks, but some wonder if the cost to personal liberty is too great.
